previous next using the emodule use this emodule before labs to prepare for them, during labs to guide your studies, and after labs as a review tool. to complete each section, use the next button at the bottom of the pages or press the right arrow key to move forward one page at a time. use the menu, available by clicking “menu” at the top, to navigate to specific slides. use search to quickly find instances of relevant terms. use the previous button at the bottom of the pages or press the left arrow key to move back one page at a time. exercise selection 3a prelab slm 3.1 the abdomi… 3.2 the abdo ca…

lab 3 exercise selection select an exercise to begin: lab 3 exercises 3.1 abdominal wall and inguinal canal 3.1 abdominal wall and inguinal canal 3.1 abdominal wall and inguinal canal 3.2 the abdominal cavity 3.2 the abdominal cavity 3.2 the abdominal cavity 3.3 overview of the pelvis 3.3 overview of the pelvis 3.3 overview of the pelvis pre-lab slm if you finish any exercise early… 3.5 field trip 3.5 field trip 3.5 field trip review lab 3 quizlandia 3 quizlandia 3 quizlandia 3 3a introduction to the abdomen 3a introduction to the abdomen 3a introduction to the abdomen instructions 3.4 practice test schedule 3.4 practice test schedule 3.4 practice test schedule

unit 1 overview previous in unit 1, students are introduced to the body wall, its contents and innervation. unit 1 includes 3, six-hour laboratory periods, during which students will complete 4 separate exercises. six hour labs occur either split up over two, 3-hour half days, or over the course of one full day . within a given lab room, students are divided into four lab groups of 8 - 9 students. these are designated lab groups a-d. the students within each of these groups will dissect, learn from, and share the care of two cadavers, one male and one female, for the duration of the academic year. each lab group (a-d) is divided into lab pairs 1-4, and each pair assigned to start the lab on one of the four exercises, 1-4. pairs will have approximately 90 minutes to complete the tasks associated with a given exercise before the at announces that it is time to rotate to the next exercise. students are not permitted to move from one station to the next until instructed to do so by the ta. if the station involves dissection, the first pair will start the dissection. if the dissection is complete before rotating, subsequent pairs will explore the structures uncovered through dissection. however, if the dissection is not complete, the next pair will continue dissecting where the last pair left off. if you are done all of the tasks at a station, and completed the end of exercise quiz in quizlandia, before it is time to rotate, click on the “field trip” button. this will provide you with a list of specimens to look at in grant’s museum of anatomy, ms1150, to help build your understanding of the material presented within each lab. all students must prepare for each lab session by completing the pre-lab slm(s) associated with the lab. each lab session begins with an app-based rat on the pre-lab slm. it is recommended that students review the lab exercises that they will complete during the session, although this content will not be tested on the rat. next

lab 3 instructions previous next prior to lab 3, you will complete exercise 3a, a short self-learning module (slm) that teaches you some basic information about the abdomen. this is to be completed before the lab. the lab will begin at 9 am and 1 pm (stg) or 10 am and 2 pm (mam) with an app-based quiz on this slm. during the lab you will complete exercises 3.1 - 3.3, in which you will study the abdominal wall and cavity, as well as the bony pelvis. you will work and rotate with your pairs, as outlined below. in addition, groups will take turns completing a practice bell-ringer test. students in labs 1162 - 1168 will complete the bell-ringer in ms1114. students in labs 1131 - 1137 will complete the bell-ringer in ms1129. 3.5 is a field trip to grant’s museum, where there are outstanding dissections of the abdominal contents, as well as a male and female pelvis. take time to study these specimens. exercise stg 9:00-10:30mam 10:00-11:30 stg 10:30-12:00 mam 11:30 - 1:00 stg 12:00-1:00 mam 1:00-1:30 stg 1:00-2:30mam 2:00-3:30 stg 2:30-4:00 mam 3:30 - 5:00 3.1 pairs 1 pairs 4 lunch pairs 3 pairs 2 3.2 pairs 2 pairs 1 lunch pairs 4 pairs 3 3.3 pairs 3 pairs 2 lunch pairs 1 pairs 4 “test” click here to see a schedule of when each group writes the practice test

previous acknowledgements acknowledgements author and emodule development: barbara ballyk, ph.d. associate professor, teaching stream division of anatomy, department of surgery faculty of medicine, university of toronto brand design: janet koecher, discovery commons university of toronto © 2019 emodule production: kristy cheung, b.sc.h., m.sc. candidate, clinical anatomy, western university albert gheorghita, m.d. candidate 2t0 faculty of medicine, university of toronto valera castanov, ph.d. m.d. candidate, faculty of medicine, queen’s university julian manzone, m.d. faculty of medicine, university of toronto

3a introduction to the abdomen previous next objectives when you have learned the material presented in this module, you will be able to: describe the structure, blood supply, and innervation of the abdominal wall. describe the structure and contents of the rectus sheath. describe the three flat muscles of the abdominal wall. describe the lymphatic drainage of the abdominal wall. describe the process of the descent of the testes. describe the structure of the inguinal canal. describe the structure and contents of the spermatic cord. differentiate between direct and indirect inguinal hernias. describe the limits of the abdominopelvic/peritoneal cavity. describe how the embryological development of abdominal organs determines their final position within the peritoneal cavity. describe the innervation of abdominal viscera
3a part 1 next previous 2 structure of the anterolateral abdominal wall

3a layers of the abdominal wall next previous the anterolateral abdominal wall is like a 7-layer dip. its layers have similarities to those of the thoracic body wall, with which you are familiar. from superficial to deep, the layers of the abdominal wall are the: 1. skin 2. superficial (camper’s) fascia, composed of loose connective tissue and a variable amount of adipose 3. deep (scarpa’s) fascia, composed of dense connective tissue 4. layers of skeletal muscle 5. transversalis fascia, which lines the inner surfaces of the muscles that form the abdominal wall, extends into the pelvis and onto the underside of the diaphragm 6. extraperitoneal fascia, composed of loose connective tissue and a variable amount of adipose parietal peritoneum, a serous membrane that lines the internal surface of the abdominal wall external oblique internal oblique transversus abdominis transversalis fascia extraperitoneal fascia parietal peritoneum superficial fascia: membranous layer (scarpa’s fascia) superficial fascia: fatty layer (camper’s fascia) skin 3

3a skeletal muscle of the abdominal wall next previous the anterolateral abdominal wall includes three broad flat muscles arranged in layers. these flat muscles begin with posterior attachments to ribs, vertebrae and pelvis, where they are fleshy and contractile. as they approach the anterior aspect of the abdominal wall, they become aponeurotic , non-contractile sheets that interlace in the midline, forming the linea alba . on either side of the linea alba, a single vertical muscle, the rectus abdominis completes the abdominal wall anteriorly. the rectus abdominis is enclosed in the rectus sheath, which is formed by the aponeuroses of the three flat muscles, as they pass anterior and posterior to the rectus abdominis. external oblique internal oblique transversus abdominis transversalis fascia extraperitoneal fascia parietal peritoneum skin visceral peritoneum superficial fascia camper’s fascia scarpa’s fascia 4 aponeuroses

3a the three flat muscles of the abdominal wall next previous the three flat muscles of the anterolateral abdominal wall are the external oblique, the internal oblique and the transversus abdominis. the fibres of each of these muscles are oriented in different directions, and can be differentiated on this basis. while the fibres of the external oblique run inferomedially, the fibres of the internal oblique run perpendicular to these, i.e. superomedially. the fibres of the deepest layer, the transversus abdominus run more horizontally. 5

3a the rectus abdominis next previous the rectus abdominis are long, paired muscles located on either side of the linea alba. they extend from the costal margin above to the pubic crest below. each is separated into three or four segments by tendinous intersections. on a fit individual, these subdivisions are easily recognizable as a “six pack”, as are the linea alba in the midline and the linea semilunaris, along the lateral borders of the rectus abdominis. external oblique rectus abdominis tendinous intersection pyramidalis linea alba transversalis fascia arcuate line internal oblique posterior wall of rectus sheath 6

3a the structure of the rectus sheath next previous the rectus sheath is formed by the aponeuroses of the three flat muscles of the anterolateral abdominal wall. along the upper ¾ of the length of the rectus abdominis, the rectus sheath has an anterior and a posterior lamina . the anterior lamina is formed by the aponeurosis of the external oblique, with a contribution from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique. the posterior lamina is formed by the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis with a contribution from the aponeurosis of the internal oblique. linea alba transversalis fascia arcuate line internal oblique posterior wall of rectus sheath linea alba linea alba internal oblique internal oblique transversalis fascia transversalis fascia parietal peritoneum external oblique external oblique rectus abdominis rectus abdominis transversus abdominis transversus abdominis 7 parietal peritoneum

linea alba transversalis fascia arcuate line internal oblique posterior wall of rectus sheath linea alba linea alba internal oblique internal oblique transversus abdominis transversalis fascia transversalis fascia parietal peritoneum external oblique external oblique rectus abdominis rectus abdominis 3a the arcuate line next previous along the lower ¼ of the rectus abdominis, all three aponeurotic layers derived from the three flat muscles pass anterior to the rectus abdominis, leaving the posterior surface of the rectus abdominis in contact with the transversalis fascia. the transition between these two structural arrangements of the rectus sheath is abrupt. it occurs roughly at the halfway point between the umbilicus and the pubic crest, where the inferior border of the posterior lamina is identifiable as the arcuate line. a. the rectus sheath above the arcuate line 8 b. the rectus sheath below the arcuate line parietal peritoneum transversus abdominis

3a the conjoint tendon next previous superior to the pubis, the aponeuroses of the internal oblique and the transversus abdominis fuse to form the conjoint tendon, which inserts into the pubic crest. this structure contributes to the inguinal canal (see 3.1 part 2). 9

3a innervation of the abdominal wall next previous the thickness of the abdominal wall is innervated by branches of the t7 - t12, and l1 spinal nerves. the ventral rami of the thoracic spinal nerves form the t7 - t11 intercostal nerves, which emerge from the costal margin to enter the abdominal wall, and the subcostal nerves. in the case of the l1 spinal nerves, the ventral rami form the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves. these nerves provide: somatic motor fibres to the skeletal muscle of the abdominal wall sensory fibres to the thickness of the abdominal wall, from the skin to the parietal peritoneum, and sympathetic postganglionic fibres to vascular smooth muscle, and to both arrector pili muscle and glands of the skin. 10

anterior cutaneous nerves of the abdomen are branches of intercostal nerves t7 - t11, the subcostal nerve (t12) and the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal (l1) nerves, but contain only sensory and sympathetic postganglionic fibres. 3a the cutaneous nerves of the abdominal wall next previous why are there no somatic motor fibres in these nerves? along the mid-axillary line, you will find lateral cutaneous nerves entering the superficial fascia. lateral cutaneous nerves of the abdomen are branches of the lower intercostal nerves and the subcostal nerve. the territories of the anterior and lateral cutaneous nerves overlap in the anterolateral body wall. 11

3a lymphatic drainage of the abdominal wall next the lymphatic drainage of the abdominal wall is divided into four quadrants: right upper quadrant left upper quadrant right lower quadrant left lower quadrant the right and left upper quadrants are drained by the right and left axillary lymph nodes. the right and left lower quadrants are drained by the superficial inguinal lymph nodes. 12 previous
3a part 2 next previous 13 descent of the testes and formation of the inguinal canal

3a development of the gonads next previous early in development, the gonads (testes and ovaries) arise in the extraperitoneal fascia of the posterior abdominal wall. a connective tissue cord, the gubernaculum, initially extends through the layers of the abdominal wall to attach each gonad to what will become the scrotum in the male, and to its homologue in the female, the labia majora. the processus vaginalis, a tubular evagination of the peritoneal cavity, forms alongside the gubernaculum, and extends into the developing scrotum. the processus vaginalis, as it passes through the layers of the abdominal wall, acquires a covering from each. gonad muscle wall gubernaculum processus vaginalis genital tubercle labioscrotal swelling 14

3a the descent of the testes i next previous as the fetus develops and enlarges, the positions of the gonads change, such that the ovaries come to rest in the pelvic cavity and the testicles, by birth, occupy the scrotum. in the male, this developmental process is called, “the descent of the testes”. gonadal blood vessels, lymphatics and nerves lengthen as the gonads migrate during development to their final position. the path taken by the testicles to the scrotum is determined by the gubernaculum, and as such, the testicles pass alongside the processus vaginalis, between it and the layers of the abdominal wall that cover it. each testis remains connected to the body by its spermatic cord, which consists of testicular vessels, nerves and lymphatics, as well as its efferent duct, the vas deferens. the testes and spermatic cord, as they pass alongside the processus vaginalis, take a covering from the each of the layers of the abdominal wall. when the descent of the testes is complete, a remnant of the gubernaculum is found in the scrotum attaching the inferior pole of the testis to the scrotum. parietal peritoneum extraperitoneal fascia transversalis fascia transversus abdominis internal oblique external oblique processus vaginalis gubernaculum testis 15

3a the descent of the testes ii next previous the passage through the abdominal wall formed by the processus vaginalis, and ultimately through which the testes pass on their way to the scrotum, is the inguinal canal. the point at which the testes pass from the extraperitoneal fascia through the transversalis fascia is called the deep inguinal ring. it is located just superior to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament. the point at which the testes pass through the external oblique aponeurosis into the superficial fascia of the abdominal wall is the superficial inguinal ring. it is located just superior to the inguinal ligament, at the pubis. the inguinal canal extends between these two landmarks. in the developed male, the spermatic cord remains within the inguinal canal. the processus vaginalis, however, closes off from the peritoneal cavity, leaving an isolated sack of serous membrane, derived from the peritoneum, in the scrotum, called the tunica vaginalis testis. 16 pelvic brim left ductus deferens deep inguinal ring inguinal canal ductus deferens testicular vessels epididymis testis tunica vaginalis superficial inguinal ring spermatic cord

3a the spermatic cord next previous remember, the deep inguinal ring is the point at which, during development, the testes pass from the extraperitoneal fascia through the transversalis fascia. the deep inguinal ring is located immediately lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. the inferior epigastric vessels are a surgical landmark for the deep inguinal ring. it is located just superior to the midpoint of the inguinal ligament, halfway between the asis and the pubic tubercle. in passing through the transversalis fascia, the testes and spermatic cord take a covering, the internal spermatic fascia. 17

3a clinical significance: location of malignancies next previous because it is derived from the abdominal wall, info lymph from the scrotum drains to the superficial inguinal nodes. however, the origin of the testes in the posterior abdominal wall has implications with regard to their lymphatic drainage and the spread of testicular cancers via lymph. the lymphatics that drain the testes drain to para-aortic lymph nodes in the posterior abdominal wall, and testicular cancer can spread via lymph here, and from here to other organs. 18

3a clinical significance: potential site for hernias next previous in women, the ovaries descend only as far as the pelvic cavity, and so the only structure that occupies the inguinal canal in a woman is a remnant of the gubernaculum, the round ligament of the uterus in both women and men, info the inguinal region is a weak point in the anterolateral abdominal wall, and is the location of inguinal hernias. inguinal hernias are, however, more common in males. 19

3a clinical significance: hernias next previous an inguinal hernia consists of info a sac of peritoneum that protrudes through the abdominal wall and into the inguinal canal. it may contain abdominal contents, such as a loop of bowel or fat. if a loop of bowel becomes incarcerated , it can cause a bowel obstruction. if the loop of bowel twists, cutting off its blood supply, it is said to be strangulated. both situations necessitate urgent surgery. 20

3a clinical significance: indirect inguinal hernias next previous an indirect inguinal hernia occurs info through a patent processus vaginalis; it therefore has a congenital component to its formation. while the processus vaginalis is usually obliterated by birth, in some it may be partially or completely patent; this determines the extent of the hernia, which may extend though the entire length of the inguinal canal and into the scrotum or labium majus. because an indirect inguinal hernia passes through the deep inguinal ring, it is therefore located lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. because the root of the problem is a patent processus vaginalis, indirect inguinal hernias commonly present as problems in babies and small children, usually male. 21

next previous a direct inguinal hernia occurs info when the hernia pushes through the abdominal wall posterior to the superficial inguinal ring, and is therefore located medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. these hernias are often referred to as “acquired”, because they are associated with the weakening of the abdominal wall that can occur with age. a direct inguinal hernia may pass through the superficial inguinal ring, into the superficial fascia, and extend into the scrotum 22 3a clinical significance: direct inguinal hernias
3a part 3 next previous 23 the abdominal cavity and contents

3a the limits of the abdominal cavity next previous the abdominal cavity extends from the inferior thoracic aperture, superiorly, to the pelvic inlet, inferiorly (see section 3.4 for the details of the pelvis). because they are continuous with each other, the abdominal and pelvic cavities are often grouped together as the abdominopelvic cavity or the peritoneal cavity. it is separated from the thoracic cavity by the diaphragm, which attaches to the margins of the inferior thoracic aperture. in contrast, the abdominal cavity is continuous with the pelvic cavity, inferiorly. the abdominal cavity is limited by the abdominal wall, the structure of which was described in section 3.1. diaphragm abdominal wall iliac crest inguinal lig. inferior thoracic aperture pelvic inlet lower limb 24

3a locations of abdominal viscera: intra- and retroperitoneal next previous abdominal viscera are either suspended within the peritoneal cavity by mesenteries, as is the gastrointestinal (gi) tract in the accompanying diagram, or they are embedded in the extraperitoneal fascia of the posterior abdominal wall, as illustrated by the position of the kidneys. the peritoneal cavity separates the internal surface of the abdominal wall from the contained organs. if they are suspended within the peritoneal cavity by mesenteries, viscera are said to be intraperitoneal. if they are embedded in the extraperitoneal fascia of the posterior abdominal wall, they are said to be retroperitoneal. note in the accompanying diagram that the aorta and inferior vena cava are in a retroperitoneal position, as are major nerves and lymphatics (not illustrated). costal margin left kidney muscles aorta inferior vena cava right kidney mesentery peritoneal cavity gastrointestinal tract 25

3a the gastrointestinal tract, mesenteries, and peritoneum i next previous at a first approximation, the gi tract can be envisioned to be much like a paper towel tube that is suspended within the peritoneal cavity. it is attached to the posterior abdominal wall along its entire length by a dorsal mesentery, but is attached to the anterior abdominal wall only along its proximal portion by a ventral mesentery. all surfaces within the peritoneal cavity, including both the internal surface of the body wall and those of the contained viscera, are lined by peritoneum, a serous membrane analogous to the pleura of the pleural cavity and the pericardium of the pericardial cavity. the peritoneal cavity normally contains only a small amount of serous fluid, called peritoneal fluid, secreted by the peritoneum. peritoneal fluid acts as a lubricant, permitting movement of the contained organs, limited by their mesenteries. aorta branch of aorta gastrointestinal tract ventral mesentery kidney – posterior to peritoneum dorsal mesentery visceral peritoneum parietal peritoneum 26

aorta branch of aorta gastrointestinal tract ventral mesentery kidney – posterior to peritoneum dorsal mesentery visceral peritoneum parietal peritoneum 3a the gastrointestinal tract, mesenteries, and peritoneum ii next previous also analogous to the pleural and pericardial cavities, the serous membrane lining the internal surface of the abdominal wall is the parietal peritoneum, and that covering the contained viscera is the visceral peritoneum. note that the mesenteries attaching the gi tract to the body wall are formed by the parietal peritoneum reflecting off the body wall and on to the contained gut tube. the dorsal mesentery contains blood vessels arising from retroperitoneal parent vessels, such as the aorta. since the gi tract is an unpaired structure, the neurovascular structures that supply it are also unpaired. 27

3a some viscera become secondarily retroperitoneal next previous during embryonic development, certain viscera, including portions of the gi tract, begin in an intraperitoneal position, but migrate to the posterior body wall and become fused there in a retroperitoneal position. such viscera are said to be secondarily retroperitoneal. note in these diagrams that the unpaired neurovascular structures supplying secondarily retroperitoneal viscera also become secondarily retroperitoneal, as these structures lose their mesenteries. visceral peritoneum gi tract artery to gi tract gi tract mesentary before fusion with wall secondary retroperitoneal part of gi tract gi tract intraperitoneal part of gi tract retroperitoneal structures parietal peritoneum mesentary 28

3a development of the lesser and greater sacs next previous as portions of the gi tract become secondarily retroperitoneal, a portion of the peritoneal cavity becomes isolated as the omental bursa or lesser sac, separate from the remainder of the peritoneal cavity, which is now called the greater sac. however, a connection between the two subdivisions of the peritoneal cavity remains, as the omental or epiploic foramen. some abdominal viscera, such as the liver, gall bladder, pancreas and spleen, develop within the mesenteries associated with the gi tract. the liver and gall bladder develop within the ventral mesentery, the spleen develops in the dorsal mesentery, and the pancreas develops from a dual origin, in each of the dorsal and ventral mesenteries. 29 dorsal pancreatic duct dorsal mesentery superior mesenteric a. stomach liver ventral mesentery gallbladder ventral pancreatic duct yolk sac omental foramen greater omentum lesser sac liver stomach

3a clinical significance: abdominal pain next previous parietal peritoneum info is supplied with sensory fibres by the somatic nerves of the body wall. pain with irritation of the parietal peritoneum is therefore somatic in nature; it is sharp and well-localized. in contrast, visceral peritoneum info is supplied with sensory fibres by the autonomic nervous system. pain with irritation of the visceral peritoneum, like that due to irritation of a viscus, is colicky and poorly-localized. 30
3a part 4 next previous 31 innervation of abdominal contents

next previous 3a autonomic innervation of abdominopelvic viscera in lab 1 you learned about the autonomic (exclusively sympathetic), innervation of the body wall. in lab 2 you learned about the autonomic (sympathetic and parasympathetic) innervation of thoracic viscera. now in lab 3 you will learn about the autonomic (sympathetic and parasympathetic) innervation of abdominopelvic viscera. as for thoracic organs, for any given abdominopelvic organ the two arms of the autonomic nervous system oppose each other. for instance, the sympathetic nervous system decreases motility and secretion of the digestive tract while the parasympathetic nervous system increases these functions. to recap of what you’ve learned so far, in lab 1 you learned that sympathetic outflow to all body targets arises from the spinal cord between segments t1 - l2; i.e. the cell bodies of sympathetic preganglionic neurons are restricted to these levels of the spinal cord. in lab 2 you learned that sympathetic output for thoracic viscera is further restricted to the t1-t4 (or t5) spinal levels, varying between individuals. preganglionic sympathetic axons leave the spinal cord via the ventral root and spinal nerve, and travel via a white ramus communicans to a sympathetic chain ganglion. these ganglia contain the cell bodies of sympathetic postganglionic neurons destined to innervate both the body wall / limbs and thoracic viscera. 32

next previous 3a sympathetic innervation of abdominopelvic viscera 33 sympathetic preganglionic neuronal cell bodies destined to innervate abdominopelvic viscera are located in the t5 - l2 spinal levels. for abdominal and pelvic viscera, the cell bodies of postganglionic neurons are not located in the sympathetic chain ganglia, they are located in ganglia associated with plexus located anterior to the vertebral column, the prevertebral plexus. as illustrated here, preganglionic sympathetic axons destined to innervate abdominopelvic viscera leave the spinal cord via the ventral root and spinal nerve, and travel via a white ramus communicans to a sympathetic chain ganglion, but they do not synapse here. these preganglionic sympathetic axons carry on through the ganglion without synapsing and may travel up or down the chain to form the thoracic (greater, lesser least), lumbar and sacral splanchnic nerves . these nerves deliver sympathetic preganglionic fibres to the ganglia associated with the prevertebral plexus. this is illustrated on your spinal cord model here: .

next previous 3a parasympathetic innervation of abdominopelvic viscera 34 parasympathetic output for most body targets arises from the brainstem and travels with select cranial nerves to targets are in the face, thorax, and the proximal abdomen. parasympathetics for targets in the distal abdomen, pelvis and perineum arises from sacral levels s2-s4 of the spinal cord, in the form of the pelvic splanchnic nerves . like the sympathetics, parasympathetic innervation of viscera involves a two-neuron chain, with the cell body of the preganglionic neuron in the cns and the cell body of the postganglionic neuron in a ganglion in the pns. for targets in the face, parasympathetic ganglia are associated with cranial nerves and are called terminal ganglia . for targets elsewhere, the ganglia are called intramural ganglia . viscera of the foregut and midgut receive parasympathetic preganglionic input from cranial nerve x, the vagus nerve. viscera of the hindgut, pelvis and perineum receive parasympathetic preganglionic input from the pelvic splanchnic nerves. in both cases, parasympathetic ganglia are located in intramural ganglia within the walls of the target organ.

next previous 3a visceral plexuses fibres from different origins combine in autonomic or visceral plexuses, where parasympathetic fibres combine with sympathetic fibres as they approach their target organs. as illustrated, sympathetic preganglionic fibres carried by thoracic, lumbar and sacral splanchnic nerves combines with parasympathetic preganglionic fibres carried by the vagus and pelvic splanchnic nerves in the prevertebral plexus. from there, mixed autonomic nerves extend to their targets in the abdomen and pelvis. these plexuses contain both sensory and motor fibres. 35
next previous 3a quiz skip 36 press or swipe next to start the quiz or skip to end exercise 3a.

congratulations on finishing slm 3a introduction to the abdomen! next exercise next exercise next exercise back to exercise selection back to exercise selection back to exercise selection review slm 3a review slm 3a review slm 3a previous
3.1 dissection of the abdominal wall and inguinal canal previous specimens cadaver 1 next what you’ll need:

3.1 objectives next previous describe the structure, blood supply, and innervation of the muscles of the abdominal wall. describe the structure and contents of the rectus sheath. identify the three flat muscles of the abdominal wall. describe the lymphatic drainage of the abdominal wall. describe the structure of the inguinal canal. describe the process of the descent of the testes. describe the structure and contents of the spermatic cord. differentiate between direct and indirect inguinal hernias. 2

3.1 removing the skin from your cadaver i next previous you will start by skinning the anterolateral abdominal wall of the cadaver from the costal margin to the proximal thigh, and laterally to the mid-axillary line. you will reflect the skin flaps laterally, leaving them attached along the mid-axillary line. you will replace these flaps at the end of your dissection, to keep the tissues moist between lab sessions. 3

3.1 removing the skin from your cadaver ii next previous refer to the accompanying diagram. the incision along the costal margin will have been done for you by technicians in preparation for lab 2. use a scalpel to make an incision tas k from the xiphoid process (a) to the pubic symphysis (b) in the midline, pausing to cut a circular incision around the umbilicus, as illustrated. note that your incisions tas k correspond to certain landmark dermatomes: t6 over the xiphisternal joint, t10 over the umbilicus, and l1 along the inguinal ligament and suprapubic region. put your scalpel down. from now on you will use a technique called “blunt dissection”, which involves the use of closed scissors, or the back of a scalpel handle or a blunt probe. it is illustrated for you in the accompanying video. 4 1. by palpation, find the anterior superior iliac spine (asis). 2. make an incision from the pubic symphysis (b) to a point 3 cm below the asis (c). 3. make a final incision transversely from the umbilicus to the midaxillary line (d).

3.1 removing the skin from your cadaver iii next previous one of each dissecting pair will work on either side of the cadaver. one will start by removing the upper right skin flap, while the other will start by removing the lower left skin flap, as follows: using large forceps, grasp the skin tas k at the corner adjacent to the umbilicus and lift it away from the body wall. you will see a layer of adipose, known as the superficial, or camper’s, fascia deep to the skin. deep to camper’s fascia is a layer of deep (scarpa’s) fascia that overlies the anterior lamina of the rectus sheath. scarpa’s fascia is a thin layer of denser ct, as compared to camper’s fascia. your goal is to remove the skin, camper’s and scarpa’s fascia as one, leaving the underlying muscle revealed and clean, ready to learn from. continue placing tension on the skin tas k with the forceps by lifting it away from the body surface. find the plane between scarpa’s fascia and the rectus sheath using blunt dissection. the rectus sheath will appear white and dense. use any of the blunt instruments suggested above to separate scarpa’s fascia from the anterior lamina of the rectus sheath; don’t use your scalpel deep to skin unless instructed to do so. once you’ve lifted the corner of the skin and fascia about 4 cm from the surface of the rectus sheath, make a “button hole” in the skin and insert your closed forceps through it. use the forceps as a handle to keep the tension on the skin and continue using blunt dissection to reflect the skin and fascia together as one. 5

understand its function, and then carry on. 3.1 the anterior cutaneous nerves next previous about 2-3 cm (~1 in) from the midline, tas k you will find anterior cutaneous nerves, which pierce through the aponeurosis of the external oblique and the deep fascia to enter the superficial fascia. anterior cutaneous nerves of the abdomen are branches of intercostal nerves t7 - t11, the subcostal nerve (t12) and the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal (l1) nerves, but contain only sensory and sympathetic postganglionic fibres. why are there no somatic motor fibres in these nerves? identify one anterior cutaneous nerve, tas k 6

3.1 the lateral cutaneous nerves next previous i.e. if you are removing the upper skin flap, move to work on the corner adjacent to the xiphisternal joint; if you are removing the lower skin flap, move to work on the corner over the pubic symphysis. repeat this, but starting at a different corner of the skin flap; tas k along the mid-axillary line, you will find lateral cutaneous nerves entering the superficial fascia. lateral cutaneous nerves of the abdomen are branches of the lower intercostal nerves and the subcostal nerve. the territories of the anterior and lateral cutaneous nerves overlap in the anterolateral body wall. again use the “button hole” technique to your advantage. continue to reflect the skin flap using blunt dissection to the midaxillary line. leave it attached along this line so that you can use the flaps to cover your work between lab sessions. 7 once you have reflected about half of the skin flap,

3.1 exposing the external oblique muscle previous musculature of the anterior body wall in its entirety. you now see the superficial surface of the external oblique and its reflect the third and fourth skin flaps, thereby revealing the tas k as the inferior, free edge, of the external oblique aponeurosis, extending from the anterior superior iliac spine to the pubic tubercle. identify the inguinal ligament aponeurosis, from the linea alba in the midline to the mid-axillary line, and from the costal margin above to the inguinal ligament, below. clean the surface of the muscle and aponeurosis thoroughly, such that you clearly see the inferomedial direction of both the muscle fibres and the collagen fibre bundles of the aponeurosis. abdominal part of pec major external oblique internal oblique inguinal ligament linea alba anterior superior iliac spine latissimus dorsi anterior superior iliac spine pectineal lig. inguinal lig. pectineal line pubic tubercle pubic symphysis lacunar lig. 8 next tas k once the first and second flaps are reflected,

3.1 exposing the rectus abdominis next previous gently pierce the anterior lamina of the rectus sheath with the sharp end of your large scissors. keeping the anterior lamina of the rectus sheath away from the muscle belly, use your scissors to extend this cut laterally across the width of the rectus abdominis, to the linea semilunaris. using forceps, lift the anterior lamina of the rectus sheath away from the muscle. tas k observe that the anterior lamina of the rectus sheath is strongly adhered at the tendinous intersections. lay your scissors flat and cut the attachment of the anterior lamina to the tendinous intersections. use your fingers to separate the anterior lamina of the rectus sheath from the muscle belly. tas k 9 return to your starting point, and using the same technique, extend the opening superiorly, 2.5 cm from the linea alba, as far as the costal margin. again, return to your starting point and this time extend this cut inferiorly to the pubic crest, this time only about 1 cm from the linea alba. on one side of the cadaver only, you will next open the anterior lamina of the rectus to expose the rectus abdominus. start just above the umbilicus, and about 2.5 cm lateral to the linea alba. reflect the anterior lamina of the rectus sheath laterally, leaving it attached along the semilunar line, to fully expose the rectus abdominis muscle.

3.1 the inferior epigastric arteries and veins next previous on its deep surface, identify the superior and inferior epigastric arteries and veins. these vessels anastomose within the rectus sheath. reflect the rectus abdominis medially. tas k look at the posterior lamina of the rectus sheath and find the arcuate line, as described in slm 3.1. notice that it is at the level of the arcuate line that the inferior epigastric vessels enter the rectus sheath from the subserous fascia. below the arcuate line, only transversalis fascia, extraperitoneal fascia and parietal peritoneum separate the rectus sheath from the abdominal contents. identify the linea alba, formed by the interlacing fibres of the aponeuroses of the three flat muscles. 10

3.1 progress check 1 next previous 11 since embarking on this exercise, you have dissected and clearly exposed the following structures / learned the answers to the following questions: what are the dermatomes for the following landmarks: xiphisternal joint, umbilicus, and the inguinal ligament and suprapubic region what is the eponym for the superficial fascia, and of what tissue is it composed? what is the eponym for the deep fascia, and of what tissue is it composed? what functional fibre types are found in cutaneous nerves? identify the linea alba, linea semilunaris, inguinal ligament; what are the attachments of the inguinal ligament? identify the tendinous intersections, anterior and posterior laminae of the rectus sheath, arcuate line, inferior epigastric arteries and veins name, in order, the layers of the abdominal wall deep to the rectus abdominis above the arcuate line. name, in order, the layers of the abdominal wall deep to the rectus abdominis below the arcuate line. if you are satisfied with the quality of your dissection, and your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next stage of the dissection.

3.1 the superficial inguinal ring next previous identify the point where the fibres of the external oblique aponeurosis diverge tas k to allow the spermatic cord (in a female, the round ligament of the uterus) to enter the superficial fascia above the pubic crest. the opening created by the diverging fibres of the external oblique aponeurosis is the superficial inguinal ring. the external oblique aponeurosis contributes to the coverings of the spermatic cord, giving rise to the external spermatic fascia. once again, clean and identify tas k the inguinal ligament, which is the inferior border of the external oblique, and extends aponeurosis of external oblique superficial inguinal ring spermatic cord external oblique anterior superior iliac spine inguinal ligament femoral artery and vein 12 on the contralateral side of the cadaver, you will next explore the three layers of flat muscles that form the lateral abdominal wall. in the inguinal region, from the anterior superior iliac spine (asis) to the pubic tubercle. muscles, vessels, nerves, and lymphatics pass between the pelvis and the anterior thigh beneath the inguinal ligament.

3.1 the ilioinguinal nerve next previous recall that the iliohypogastric and ilioinguinal nerves (l1) contribute to the cutaneous innervation of the anterior abdominal wall over the pubis. a branch of the ilioinguinal nerve passes from the abdominal wall through the superficial inguinal ring into the superficial fascia of the scrotum / labia majora to supply cutaneous fibres to the overlying skin. look for this branch tas k of the ilioinguinal nerve emerging from the superficial inguinal ring and running along the anterior surface of the spermatic cord. 13

3.1 exposing the internal oblique muscle next previous expose the internal oblique as follows: tas k starting just above the anterior superior iliac spine, insert the end of a blunt probe between the fibres of the external oblique to create an opening between it and the internal oblique. lift this opening away from the underlying muscle with the probe and insert your scissors. working the external oblique aponeurosis of external oblique inguinal ligament linea alba anterior superior iliac spine 14 muscle layers apart with your fingers as you go, make a vertical incision in the external oblique up to the level of the umbilicus, or higher. gently work your fingers into this incision medially to separate the muscle layers. still using large scissors, make a horizontal incision as far as the linea semilunaris. continue to separate the muscle layers with your fingers, this time in an inferior direction. cut the external oblique aponeurosis just lateral to the linea semilunaris downward to the superficial inguinal ring. reflect the flap of external oblique inferiorly, exposing the internal oblique. note the direction of its muscle fibres; they run superomedially, perpendicular to those of the external oblique.

3.1 the conjoint tendon next previous superior to the pubis, the aponeuroses of the internal oblique and the transversus abdominis fuse to form the conjoint tendon, which inserts into the pubic crest. this structure contributes to the inguinal canal. 15 look at the internal oblique muscle in the inguinal region tas k and note its inferior fibres take origin from the inguinal ligament and arch over the spermatic cord to form the conjoint tendon posterior and medial to the superficial inguinal ring. in this position, it reinforces the abdominal wall behind the superficial inguinal ring.

3.1 the cremaster muscle/fascia next previous look for fibres of the internal oblique that join the spermatic cord. tas k these fibres form the cremaster muscle / fascia. these muscle fibres contract in the cremasteric reflex, pulling the testicle closer to the body wall. the cremasteric reflex maintains testicular temperature at the ideal level for spermatogenesis . the cremaster muscle is innervated by the genitofemoral nerve. 16

3.1 exposing the transversus abdominis i next previous the ilioinguinal nerve will have been exposed further with reflection of the external oblique muscle follow the ilioinguinal nerve to the point where it disappears deep to the internal oblique tas k to run in the plane between internal oblique and the transversus abdominis. insert a blunt probe into the opening through which the nerve passes and gently enlarge it. 17 make two vertical cuts in the muscle as far as the inguinal ligament. reflect the internal oblique inferiorly, to expose the transversus abdominis. insert your finger into the opening and gently work the two muscles layers apart, enlarging the plane between them as far as the linea semilunaris. use scissors to cut the internal oblique along this horizontal line.

3.1 exposing the transversus abdominis ii next previous observe the following: tas k like the internal oblique, the lower fibres of the transversus abdominis take origin from 18 the inguinal ligament and arch over the spermatic cord. the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis fuses with that of the internal oblique to form the conjoint tendon, as described above. note the direction of the muscle fibres of the transversus abdominus; at the level of the umbilicus, they run horizontally. inferior to this level, the do begin to run inferomedially, like the external oblique.

3.1 the deep inguinal ring is lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels next previous remember, the deep inguinal ring is the point at which, during development, the testes pass from the extraperitoneal fascia through the transversalis fascia. it is located just superior to the midpoint of the grasp the spermatic cord and gently tas k pull it inferiorly. using the tip of a blunt probe, elevate the fibres of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. in the opening thus created, you will see the transversalis fascia, and through it, the inferior epigastric vessels, located in the extraperitoneal fascia, and tracking for the arcuate line where they enter the rectus sheath. the inferior epigastric vessels are a landmark for the deep inguinal ring, which is located just lateral to these vessels. you may see the vas deferens diverging from the other components of the spermatic cord at this point. inguinal ligament, halfway between the asis and the pubic tubercle. in passing through the transversalis fascia, the testes and spermatic cord take a covering, the internal spermatic fascia. 19

3.1 progress check 2 next previous 20 since the last progress check, you have dissected and clearly exposed the following structures / learned the answers to the following questions: identify the superficial inguinal ring. what passes through it in males? in females? what nerve passes through it? identify this nerve and state its function. what does the external oblique contribute to the spermatic cord? identify the inguinal ligament. what is it and what are its attachments? identify the external oblique, internal oblique and transversus abdominis. identify the conjoint tendon. what is it and what is its relationship to the superficial inguinal ring? what is the cremaster muscle? from what layer of the abdominal wall is it derived? what nerve innervates it and what is its function? identify the transversus abdominis, deep inguinal ring and inferior epigastric vessels. what is the deep inguinal ring? what is the relationship between the deep inguinal ring and the inferior epigastric vessels? if you are satisfied with the quality of your dissection, and your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next stage of the exercise, the quiz.

3.2 overview of the abdominal cavity and organs previous specimens cadaver 2 next what you’ll need:

3.2 objectives next previous explore the spaces within the peritoneal cavity and identify the abdominal organs and their features. identify the mesenteries within the peritoneal cavity. identify features of the male and female pelvic cavities. 2

3.2 exploring the peritoneum next previous reflect the plastic sheet inferiorly to uncover as much of the cadaver as necessary to study the abdominal cavity. technical staff will have opened the abdominal cavity of your cadaver as per the accompanying figure. reflect the right, left, and inguinal flaps tas k leaving the falciform flap in place. touch the inner surface of the abdominal wall and note that it is smooth and slippery. look through the tas k parietal peritoneum and you will be able to see the adipose of the extraperitoneal / subserous fascia. if you encounter adhesions while reflecting the skin flaps, work them apart with your fingers. it is covered by parietal peritoneum. you will locate structures within the peritoneal cavity using the four quadrant system. 3

3.2 the liver and its associated structures next previous identify the liver, tas k the bulk of which is located in the upper right quadrant of the peritoneal cavity. touch the diaphragmatic surface of the liver and note that it is smooth and slippery. it is covered by visceral peritoneum. gently pull the falciform flap tas k away from the liver and identify the falciform ligament , which is a remnant of the ventral mesentery that attaches the liver to the underside of the diaphragm and to the anterior abdominal wall as far inferiorly as the umbilicus. observe that the falciform ligament tas k is composed of two layers of peritoneum that joins the parietal peritoneum of the body wall with the visceral peritoneum of the liver. in the inferior free edge of the falciform ligament, identify the round ligament of the liver, and observe that it extends to the umbilicus. it is a remnant of the umbilical vein, which brought oxygenated blood from the umbilical cord to the fetal liver. gray’s atlas p.142 4

3.2 the sub-phrenic spaces next previous identify the right and left lobes of the liver, tas k separated by the falciform ligament. slide your hand between tas k the right lobe of the liver and the underside of the diaphragm. your hand is in the right sub-phrenic space. slide your hand between tas k the left lobe of the liver and the underside of the diaphragm. your hand is in the left sub-phrenic space. identify the gall bladder, tas k also located in the right upper quadrant, and extending out from under the inferior border of the liver. confirm its relationship adjacent to the 9th costal cartilage in the right midclavicular line. gray’s atlas p.142 5

3.2 the sub-hepatic spaces next previous slide your hand between tas k the stomach and the left lobe of the liver. your hand is in the left sub-hepatic space. slide your hand between tas k the stomach and the right lobe of the liver. your hand is in the right sub-hepatic space. the right sub-hepatic space is the larger of the two, and is also known as the hepatorenal recess and as the pouch of morrison. liver xiphoid process stomach greater omentum 6

3.2 exposing the components of the superior quadrants i next previous retract the inferior border of the liver superiorly to reveal the extent of the stomach in the tas k left upper quadrant. the stomach receives food from the esophagus, proximally, and empties into the duodenum of the small intestine, distally. identify the first part of the duodenum, and note that it quickly disappears from view. tas k this is because while the stomach is intraperitoneal, the duodenum is largely secondarily retroperitoneal, and it therefore disappears into the retroperitoneal fascia of the posterior body wall. 7

3.2 exposing the components of the superior quadrants ii next previous with the inferior border of the liver retracted, tas k identify the lesser omentum, and its subdivisions, the hepatogastric and hepatoduodenal ligaments. note that it extends from the lesser curvature of the stomach to the visceral surface of the liver. the lesser omentum is a derivative of the ventral mesentery, and as such, connects the visceral peritoneum of the stomach with that of the liver. it contains within its layers blood vessels that supply the stomach and liver, as well as ducts which convey the exocrine secretions of the liver to the duodenum. 8

3.2 exposing the components of the superior quadrants iii next previous all of the spaces within the peritoneal cavity that you have been exploring so far are parts of the greater sac. the lesser sac is posterior to the stomach, and therefore hidden from view. the continuity between these two subdivisions of the peritoneal sac is the epiploic (omental) foramen, which is located behind the hepatoduodenal ligament of the lesser omentum. gently insert your index finger tas k through the epiploic foramen and into the lesser sac. 9

3.2 the spleen next previous the spleen is located in the upper left quadrant, and, as illustrated in the accompanying cross section, it is posterior to the stomach. reach behind the stomach tas k with your right hand and feel for the spleen. it is an intraperitoneal organ with a smooth surface and should fit in your hand, unless it is enlarged. gently reflect the stomach to the right side and try to look at the spleen. it will be deep red to purple in colour because of its rich blood supply. falciform lig. lesser omentum gastric vessels stomach omental bursa spleen left kidney aorta txii ivc right kidney greater sac omental foramen liver portal vein bile duct hepatic artery proper 10

3.2 the greater omentum next previous identify the greater omentum tas k and its attachment to the greater curvature of the stomach. the greater omentum is an expanded derivative of the dorsal mesentery that extends from the greater curvature of the stomach to the posterior body wall. it contains within its layers some of the blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics that supply the stomach. gray’s atlas p.142 11

3.2 the supracolic and infracolic compartments next previous 12 reflect the greater omentum tas k superiorly, and identify the transverse colon adhered to its posterior surface. the greater omentum and transverse colon separate the supracolic compartment from the infracolic compartment. these are the two major subdivisions of the greater sac. the subphrenic and subhepatic spaces, which you have already identified, are parts of the supracolic compartment. this concludes your exploration of the structures and spaces of the supracolic compartment.

3.2 progress check 1 next previous 13 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify parietal and visceral peritoneum. what is extraperitoneal fascia? identify the liver lobes, falciform ligament, round ligament (what is it?), right and left subphrenic spaces, gall bladder (what is its surface anatomy landmark?), left and right subhepatic space, stomach, greater and lesser curvatures, first part of duodenum, lesser omentum and its subdivisions, epiploic foramen (what two spaces does it connect?), spleen, greater omentum, transverse colon, supracolic and infracolic compartments if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next stage of the exercise.

3.2 the large intestine is both intraperitoneal and secondarily retroperitoneal next previous with the greater omentum tas k reflected superiorly, identify the large intestine and its components: the cecum and ileocecal junction in the lower right quadrant the ascending colon the transverse colon the descending colon the sigmoid colon observe that both tas k the ascending and descending colons are fixed in place to the posterior abdominal wall, as these portions of the gi tract are secondarily retroperitoneal. identify the transverse mesocolon tas k and the sigmoid mesocolon, which are the mesenteries of the transverse and sigmoid colons, respectively, and contain the blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics that supply these portions of the gi tract. grant’s atlas fig 2.42 14

3.2 the small intestine takes up most of the abdominal cavity next previous identify tas k the loops of small intestine. within the “frame” of the ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid colon. although there is no sharp border between these two subdivisions, the jejunum largely occupies the left upper quadrant, while the ileum largely occupies the right lower quadrant. you will not see the duodenum because, as noted previously, it is secondarily retroperitoneal. however, the remainder of the small intestine, the jejunum and ileum, are intraperitoneal and clearly visible. grant’s atlas fig 2.42 15

3.2 the mesentery of the small intestine next gently reflect the small intestine first toward the right side tas k this mesentery contains the blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics that supply the jejunum and ileum. note that its attachment tas k to the posterior body wall extends obliquely from the upper left quadrant to the lower right quadrant. transverse colon jejunum descending colon duodenojejunal junction sigmoid colon sigmoid mesocolon ileum aorta mesentery of small intestine gastrocolic part of greater omentum a a. transverse colon haustra semi-lunar fold taeniae coli grant’s atlas fig 2.41 16 of the peritoneal cavity and identify its mesentery. next, gently push the small intestine the left side of the peritoneal cavity and again identify its mesentery. the mesentery and its attachment to the posterior body wall subdivides the infracolic compartment into a right infracolic compatment and a left infracolic compartment. run your hand along the space lateral to the ascending and descending colons. these are the right and left paracolic gutters, respectively. previous

3.2 the transverse mesocolon and the greater omentum: huh? next previous observe that the transverse colon tas k and its mesentery are fixed to the underside of the greater omentum. this occurs in the early postnatal period, as illustrated in this figure from grant’s atlas of anatomy, when these two derivatives of the dorsal mesentery fuse. grant’s atlas fig 2.24 17

3.2 the male pelvic cavity next previous identify, in the pelvis, the rectum, tas k the superior surface of the urinary bladder, and the space in between, the rectovesical pouch. at the midpoint of the inguinal ligament, through the parietal peritoneum, identify the deep inguinal ring where the testicular vessels and the vas deferens diverge. remember, the deep inguinal ring is just lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels. * when you are finished, visit the adjacent group, whose cadaver 1 is female and identify the structures and spaces in the female pelvis, as outlined in the next slide. grant’s atlas fig 3.20 18 if the cadaver you are studying is male*,

3.2 the female pelvic cavity next previous tas k identify in the pelvis, the rectum, uterus and identify the vesicouterine pouch between the urinary bladder and the uterus. look for: tas k the uterine (fallopian) tubes and ovaries. lastly, find the round ligament of the ovaries, tas k which is the remnant of the gubernaculum in the female, extending to the deep inguinal ring. again, use the inferior epigastric vessels as a landmark for the deep inguinal ring. grant’s atlas fig 3.33 superior view *when you are finished, visit the adjacent group, whose cadaver 1 is male and identify the structures and spaces in the male pelvis, as outlined on the previous slide. 19 if the cadaver you are studying is female*, the superior surface of the urinary bladder. identify the rectouterine pouch (of douglas) between the rectum and uterus.

3.2 progress check 2 next previous 20 since the last progress check, you have identified the following structures / learned the answers to the following questions: identify the large intestine (cecum, ileocecal junction, ascending, transverse, descending and sigmoid colon). which parts of the large intestine are secondarily retroperitoneal? which parts are intraperitoneal and what is the name of their mesenteries? identify the small intestine and its mesentery; identify, roughly, the jejunum and ileum. what are the subdivisions of the infracolic compartment that are separated by the small intestine and its mesentery? name the spaces lateral to the ascending and descending colon. in the male cadaver, identify the rectum, urinary bladder, rectovesical pouch, deep inguinal ring, inferior epigastric vessels. in the female cadaver, identify the rectum, uterus, urinary bladder, rectouterine pouch, vesicouterine pouch, fallopian tubes, ovaries, round ligament of the ovaries, deep inguinal ring, inferior epigastric vessels. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next stage of the exercise, the quiz.

3.3 the bony pelvis: overview of the male and female pelves previous specimens articulated pelvis isolated pelvic bones hemi pelvis with major ligaments prosections of male and female pelves next what you’ll need:

3.3 objectives next previous 1. describe the bones that form the pelvis 2. describe the structure of the articulated pelvis, including major ligaments 3. compare and contrast the structure of the male and female pelvis 4. describe the male and female pelvic viscera and associated spaces. 2

3.3 the bones of the pelvis next previous the pelvis is formed by four bones, the two ossa coxae (hip bones), the sacrum and the coccyx. you are already familiar with the latter two bones from your initial study of the vertebral column. since you are already familiar with the isolated sacrum and coccyx, you will start by studying the isolated os coxa (hip bone). pick up a hip bone tas k from the bones with which you’ve been provided. identify its lateral surface by identify these subdivisions: tas k ilium ischium pubis 3 finding the acetabulum, which articulates with the head of the femur to form the hip joint. the hip bone is formed from three bones that are separate, but joined by cartilage at birth, and fuse with physical maturity.
3.3 the lateral surface of the hip bone next previous on the lateral surface tas k of the hip bone, identify the features indicated on the accompanying diagram. g5.21b 4
3.3 the medial surface of the hip bone next previous turn the bone over, tas k and on the medial surface of the hip bone, identify the features indicated on the accompanying diagram. g5.21a 5

3.3 articulations of the pelvis next previous pick up the sacrum from amongst the bones tas k with which you’ve been provided and articulate it properly with the hip bone in your hand, as per fig a. identify the sacroiliac joint. pick up the second hip bone, tas k as per inset b. identify the location of the pubic symphysis, which joins the two pubic bones in the anterior midline. gray’s atlas p.202 6

3.3 the true and false pelvis next previous turn your attention to the model of a pelvis with which you have been provided. the pelvis is shaped like a fancy cocktail glass. it has a larger, upper bowl (a) and a smaller lower bowl (b). identify the larger, upper bowl, tas k the false pelvis. it borders the lower abdominal wall and contains abdominal organs. identify the smaller, lower bowl, tas k the true pelvis. it contains pelvic organs. identify the plane that separates the false and true pelvis; this is the pelvic inlet. 7
3.3 the pelvic inlet next previous run your fingers around tas k the margin of the pelvic inlet and note the bony features that contribute to it, as illustrated in the figure. 8

3.3 the pelvis in anatomical position next previous you have been holding the pelvis incorrectly! hold the pelvis tas k in anatomical position, as in the figure, by placing the asis and the pubic tubercles in the same vertical plane. notice the orientation tas k of the pelvic inlet: it is tipped very much forward. 9

3.3 there are numerous ligaments i next previous the articulations between the bones of the pelvis are reinforced by numerous, strong ligaments, a subset of which will be described at this point. the sacrotuberous ligament and the sacrospinous ligament close off the greater and lesser sciatic notches, forming the greater and lesser sciatic foramina . the obturator membrane closes off the obturator foramen almost entirely, leaving a small opening, the obturator canal. 10

3.3 there are numerous ligaments ii next previous of the ligamentous hemipelvis. identify the sacrotuberous and unwrap the prosection tas k 11 sacrospinous ligaments. identify the greater and lesser sciatic foramina. as it is difficult to preserve, the obturator membrane may not be present in the prosection.

3.3 contributions of the pelvic outlet next previous the sacrotuberous ligaments also contribute to the margin of the pelvic outlet, along with the ischiopubic rami, the pubic symphysis and the coccyx. most of the pelvic outlet is enclosed by the pelvic diaphragm, also called the pelvic floor, a funnel-shaped sheet of skeletal muscle that separates the true pelvis from the perineum. the perineum is defined as the region between the thighs, below the pelvic diaphragm. pubic symphysis pubic tubercle obturator foramen asis ischial tuberosity margin of pelvic outlet coccyx sacrum acetabulum ischiopubic ramus 12

3.3 structures pass through openings in the pelvis next previous the openings created by the addition of these ligaments to the bony pelvis allow for communication between the true pelvis and other regions. structures, such as muscles, nerves, blood vessels and lymphatics pass through these openings. for example: between the true pelvis and the gluteal region through the greater sciatic foramen between the perineum and the gluteal region through the lesser sciatic foramen an infant must pass through the pelvic inlet, true pelvis and pelvic outlet during childbirth between the true pelvis and the medial thigh through the obturator canal and finally, 13

3.3 the difference between males and females next previous largely to accommodate childbirth, the female pelvis is different from the male pelvis. the pelvis in the female has a larger, more circular pelvic inlet; that of the male pelvis is often described as, “heart shaped”, because the sacral promontory impinges on the pelvic inlet from the posterior aspect. the distance between the ischial spines is the narrowest point in the birth canal. this dimension is smaller in men, because the ischial spines in the male pelvis are more prominent and project more medially into the true pelvis. the infrapubic angle is larger in women than in men. this results in greater separation of the ischial tuberosities, which widens the pelvic outlet for passage of a baby. 14

3.3 progress check 1 next previous 15 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the features of the os coxa, as outlined. identify the features of the sacroiliac joint and pubic symphysis. differentiate between the true and false pelvis; what is the name of the plane that separates them? what are its borders? describe the attachments of the sacrotuberous and sacrospinous ligaments and the obturator membrane. identify these structures and the greater and lesser sciatic foramina in a prosection. what are the borders of the pelvic outlet? define the term “perineum”. what regions are connected through the greater sciatic foramen? lesser sciatic foramen? obturator canal? describe the anatomical differences between the male and female pelves. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next stage of the exercise.

3.3 anatomy of the male pelvis i next previous unwrap the prosection of the male hemi-pelvis tas k remember to moisten, wrap and bag the prosection as soon as you are finished with it. use only a blunt probe to examine the prosection. you must not dissect a prosection. 16

3.3 anatomy of the male pelvis ii next previous on the prosected specimen, tas k identify the structures labelled in the figure. you might have difficulty finding the seminal vesicle and ejaculatory duct. note that the prostate gland tas k is inferior to the bladder and anterior to the rectum and that the urethra passes through it. s1 vertebral body vertebral canal gastrointestinal system rectum anal canal anal aperture bladder urethra urinary system reproductive system deep inguinal ring seminal vesicle ductus deferens pubic symphysis prostate ejaculatory duct 17

s1 vertebral body vertebral canal gastrointestinal system rectum anal canal anal aperture bladder urethra urinary system reproductive system deep inguinal ring seminal vesicle ductus deferens pubic symphysis prostate ejaculatory duct 3.3 anatomy of the male pelvis iii next previous identify the peritoneum tas k lining the pelvic cavity. notice that it covers the superior surface of the urinary bladder, the lateral wall of the pelvis, and the anterolateral surface of the rectum. this creates a rectovesical pouch between the rectum and urinary bladder. through the peritoneum, tas k identify the ductus deferens and the deep inguinal ring where the ductus deferens emerges from the inguinal canal. moisten, wrap and bag the prosection. 18

3.3 anatomy of the female pelvis i next previous unwrap the prosection of the female hemi-pelvis tas k again, remember to moisten, wrap and bag the prosection as soon as you are finished with it. use only a blunt probe to examine the prosection. you must not dissect a prosection. 19

3.3 anatomy of the female pelvis ii next previous on the prosected specimen, identify the structures labelled in the figure. tas k note that the uterus is superior to the bladder, and that the vagina is between the urinary bladder and rectum. s1 vertebral body vertebral canal gastrointestinal system rectum anal canal anal aperture bladder urethra urinary system reproductive system deep inguinal ring pubic symphysis uterine tube ovary uterus vagina 20

3.3 anatomy of the female pelvis iii next previous identify the peritoneum lining the pelvic cavity. tas k notice that it covers the superior surface of the urinary bladder, reflects off the urinary bladder to cover most of the uterus, and then reflects off the uterus to cover the anterolateral surface of the rectum. this creates a vesicouterine pouch between the urinary bladder and the uterus, and a rectouterine pouch (of douglas) between the rectum and the uterus. the peritoneum clothes the lateral wall of the pelvis, and in passing over the uterine tubes, forms a poncho-like structure, the broad ligament that contains the uterine blood vessels, nerves and lymphatics. it also contains the round ligament of the uterus, the remnant of the fetal gubernaculum (see exercise 3.2), which extends to the deep inguinal ring to enter the inguinal canal. identify the above structures tas k on the prosection. 21

3.3 progress check 2 next previous 22 since the last progress check, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: in the male half-pelvis, identify the pubic symphysis, sacral segments, urinary bladder, urethra, prostate gland, rectum and anal canal. identify the rectovesical pouch, deep inguinal ring and ductus deferens. in the female half-pelvis, identify the pubic symphysis, sacral segments, urinary bladder, urethra, uterus, vagina, fallopian tube, ovary, round ligament of the uterus, rectum and anal canal. identify the rectovesical pouch, deep inguinal ring and ductus deferens. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on to the next stage of the exercise, the quiz.
